paragraphs.content: A while loop is used to repeateadly execute a block of code (loop through) while a specific condition is met. It is similiar to a for loop but a for loop is used when the programmer knows exactly when to end the loop.

paragraphs.subheading: How to create a while loop
paragraphs.content: Look at the example below. Within the brackets after 'while', there is a single statement which defines the condition which must be met in order for the loop to execute the block of code in the while loop.
The first statement 'int i = 0;' creates the variable that will indicate which iteration the loop is on. 'i' stands for index and commonly used in loops in Java.

images.caption: 'The first statement of a for loop'

paragraphs.content: The second statement 'i < 10;' specifies the period for the loop to run. If this statement is true, the loop continues. In this case, the loop ends when the index 'i' is bigger than 10.

images.caption: 'The second statement of a for loop'

paragraphs.content: The third statement 'i++' specifies how much to increment the index by on each iteration of the loop. In this case, it increments by 1 on each loop.

images.caption: 'The third statement of a for loop'
